A ring R is called commutative if the multiplication is commutative.
For an element $a \in R$, the principal ideal generated by $a$ is $R a:=\{r a ; r \in R\}$. It is the smallest ideal in $R$ containing $a$.
Does the concept of a/an Commutative Ring need to be defined for a definition of a/an Principal Ideal to make sense? (True if the first concept is needed and False if is not.)

Explanation: The definition of a Principal Ideal involves an element $a$ from a ring $R$ and considers the set of all products $ra$ for $r \text{ in } R$. This definition inherently requires the structure of a ring because it involves the ring operations (specifically multiplication). However, the definition of a Principal Ideal itself does not specify that the ring $R$ must be commutative; it only requires that $R$ be a ring. Therefore, while a ring structure is necessary for the definition of a Principal Ideal, the property of the ring being commutative (as defined in the Commutative Ring concept) is not a prerequisite. Thus, the concept of a Commutative Ring is not necessary for the definition of a Principal Ideal to make sense; any ring (whether commutative or not) suffices for the definition of a Principal Ideal.
